original_sent: And I fully expect it will return to solid growth and a solid labor market as well.
text_output:
NEUTRAL
The sentence does not contain any explicit indication of a hawkish or dovish stance towards monetary policy. It simply expresses an expectation of solid growth and a solid labor market.

original_sent: In fact, it’s already—it’s already understood, I think, that—that there’s more—even though we’re at 3½ percent unemployment, there’s actually more slack out there, in a sense.
text_output: DOVISH - The sentence suggests that despite the low unemployment rate, there is still room for improvement in the labor market, indicating a need for further monetary policy easing.

original_sent: Admittedly, some of the wage increases is being eaten away by inflation.
text_output: DOVISH - The sentence suggests that inflation is eating away at wage increases, indicating that the current monetary policy may be too tight. This implies a need for easing of the policy, hence the classification as 'DOVISH'.

original_sent: Our current framework for implementing monetary policy is working very well.
text_output:
NEUTRAL
The sentence does not indicate any bias towards tightening or easing of monetary policy, but rather expresses satisfaction with the current framework. Therefore, it can be classified as neutral.

original_sent: And as I mentioned earlier, the unemployment decline last month was more than 100 percent accounted for by declines in participation.
text_output:
NEUTRAL
The sentence does not express a clear stance on monetary policy, but rather provides information on the recent unemployment decline and its cause.

original_sent: So unemployment has tended to go up much faster for minorities and for others who are—tend to be at the low end of the income spectrum.
text_output:
NEUTRAL

This sentence does not provide any indication of a stance towards tightening or easing of monetary policy. It is simply a statement about the correlation between unemployment and income level for certain groups. Therefore, the sentence is classified as NEUTRAL.

original_sent: But many other commodity prices have fallen further, and the reason I would give for that is that the emerging markets—China, the rest of Asia, and some other parts of the world—plus Europe, of course, are softer, and so global commodity demand is weaker.
text_output:
NEUTRAL

The sentence provides an explanation for the fall in many commodity prices, attributing it to weaker global commodity demand due to softer emerging markets and Europe. The sentence does not express a clear stance on monetary policy, therefore it is classified as NEUTRAL.

original_sent: The persistence of that into, into inflation over time is just not there.
text_output: DOVISH - The sentence suggests that there is no persistence in inflation over time, indicating that the economy may not be performing as well as expected. This could lead to a potential easing of monetary policy to stimulate growth.

original_sent: But also we want to see inflation move up back to our 2 percent objective over the medium term, and so seeing above-trend growth and continuing tightness—greater tightness in labor and product markets—I think that will help us achieve our objective as well with respect to inflation.
text_output:
HAWKISH
The speaker is indicating a desire to see inflation move up to the 2 percent objective, and believes that above-trend growth and greater tightness in labor and product markets will help achieve this objective. This suggests a preference for tighter monetary policy.

original_sent: So, as you know, the ultimate focus that we have is on the real economy: maximum employment and price stability.
text_output: NEUTRAL - The sentence does not indicate a clear bias towards either tightening or easing of monetary policy. It simply states the ultimate focus of the Federal Reserve, which is on achieving maximum employment and price stability in the real economy.

original_sent: You know, what you hear out there is that demand—you talk to banks, and they’ll say demand for loans is very, very low right now.
text_output: DOVISH - The sentence suggests that there is currently low demand for loans, which could indicate a weak economy. This could lead to a dovish stance, as the central bank may consider easing monetary policy to stimulate economic growth.

original_sent: Finally, I would like to note that the Committee strives to explain its monetary policy decisions as clearly as possible, and we continue to explore ways of enhancing the clarity of our public communications.
text_output: NEUTRAL: The sentence does not express any clear stance on monetary policy. It simply states that the Committee aims to communicate its decisions clearly and is looking for ways to improve its public communications.

original_sent: If we think that the potential growth rate of the economy is somewhere between, somewhere around 1.75 percent, 2.8 percent is strong economic growth.
text_output:
NEUTRAL
The sentence provides a factual statement about the potential growth rate of the economy and does not express a clear stance on monetary policy. Therefore, it is classified as neutral.

original_sent: We also said we wouldn’t raise rates just in response to very low unemployment, in the absence of inflation.
text_output:
NEUTRAL
The sentence does not express a clear stance on monetary policy. It simply states a condition for raising interest rates, which is the presence of inflation despite low unemployment.

original_sent: Monetary policy has a role, and it really is in, you know—our original role was providing liquidity to financial systems when they’re under stress, and that’s—that’s really part of what we did today.
text_output:
NEUTRAL
The sentence does not express a clear stance on whether the monetary policy should be tightened or eased. It simply describes the role of monetary policy in providing liquidity to financial systems during times of stress. Therefore, the sentence can be classified as neutral.

original_sent: Monetary policy, maximum employment, stable prices—it’s less obvious to me.
text_output:
NEUTRAL
The sentence does not express a clear stance on monetary policy, maximum employment, or stable prices. It is simply stating that the speaker finds it less obvious. Therefore, the sentence can be classified as neutral.

original_sent: But, I would say, overall, we’re trying to sustain the expansion and keep, you know, close to our statutory goals, which are maximum employment and stable prices.
text_output: NEUTRAL - The sentence does not indicate any clear bias towards tightening or easing of monetary policy. The speaker is simply stating that the goal is to sustain the expansion and achieve maximum employment and stable prices, which is in line with the Federal Reserve's mandate.

original_sent: You know, monetary policy is a forward-looking exercise, and I’m going to—I’m just going to stick with that.
text_output: NEUTRAL - The sentence does not express any clear stance on whether the monetary policy should be tightened or eased. It simply acknowledges that monetary policy is a forward-looking exercise.

original_sent: The jobs picture continues to be strong, with the unemployment rate near historic lows and with stronger wage gains.
text_output:
NEUTRAL

The sentence simply provides a factual statement about the current state of the job market without indicating any particular stance towards monetary policy.

original_sent: You know, stimulating aggregate demand is one thing, but where there’s a part of the economy that kind of will be resistant to that, you also need fiscal policy.
text_output:
DOVISH

The sentence suggests that stimulating aggregate demand alone may not be sufficient to boost the economy, and that fiscal policy may also be necessary. This implies a preference for a more accommodative monetary policy stance, which is consistent with a dovish view.

original_sent: And what it is is, it’s an expression of the thinking about individual Committee members about appropriate monetary policy and the path of the economy.
text_output:
NEUTRAL

The sentence simply describes the purpose of the expression without indicating any bias towards tightening or easing of monetary policy. Therefore, it can be classified as neutral.

original_sent: At the time of our FOMC meeting in January, prospects for continued economic growth remained favorable, and we judged that monetary policy was well positioned to support that outlook.
text_output:
NEUTRAL

The sentence does not indicate any bias towards tightening or easing of monetary policy. It simply states that the economic growth prospects were favorable and the current monetary policy was well positioned to support that outlook.

original_sent: I mean, we—the—again, the relationship between slack in the economy and inflation is weak, has been weak.
text_output: NEUTRAL - The sentence does not express a clear stance on monetary policy. It is simply stating a fact about the relationship between slack in the economy and inflation.

original_sent: So it’s a double whammy coming from higher gasoline prices.
text_output: NEUTRAL - The sentence does not provide any indication of the stance towards monetary policy. It simply states that there is a negative impact from higher gasoline prices.

original_sent: So we do say that risks to the financial system—we say in our longer-run statement of goals and monetary policy strategy that risks to the financial system that could prevent us from achieving our goals are something that we do take into consideration.
text_output: NEUTRAL: The sentence does not express a clear stance on monetary policy. It simply acknowledges that risks to the financial system are taken into consideration when setting goals and strategies.

original_sent: You know, it says that we will seek to—seek inflation that runs moderately above 2 percent for some time.
text_output: DOVISH - The sentence suggests that the FOMC is willing to tolerate inflation moderately above the target of 2 percent for some time, indicating a willingness to ease monetary policy.

original_sent: It’s where we always want inflation to be heading.

NEUTRAL
The sentence does not indicate any specific stance towards monetary policy. It simply states a desire for inflation to be heading in a certain direction, without specifying any particular policy action to achieve that goal.

original_sent: We continue to discuss whether or not the unemployment rate itself is an adequate measure of how much underutilization of labor resources there really is.

NEUTRAL

original_sent: For example, we have used some of our work to look at interest rate risk and interest rate sensitivity and, you know, found generally that banks can also sustain a significant increase in long-term interest rates as well for a number of reasons, one of them being that higher interest rates increase their franchise value because it increases their net interest margin over time.
text_output:
NEUTRAL

The sentence does not express a clear stance on monetary policy. It simply presents findings related to interest rate risk and sensitivity in banks, and how higher interest rates can benefit them.

NEUTRAL

original_sent: So there’s been a number of emerging markets—as you know, we’re suffering under the weight of declines in oil prices that are affecting their economic activity.
text_output:
NEUTRAL
The sentence does not express a clear stance on monetary policy. It is simply stating a fact about the impact of declining oil prices on emerging markets.

original_sent: You’ll never get inflation to 2 percent.” Some of our critics now who say inflation’s too tight—too high were the same ones who were saying, “You’ll never get to 2 percent.” Well, but anyway, that’s what happened.
text_output: DOVISH - The sentence suggests that the critics who were previously concerned about high inflation are now proven wrong as inflation has not reached the target of 2 percent. This implies that there is no urgency to tighten the monetary policy and instead, there may be a need to ease it to achieve the inflation target.

original_sent: By the way, we’re also not at maximum employment, as I mentioned.
text_output: NEUTRAL - The sentence does not indicate a clear stance on monetary policy. It simply states a fact that the maximum employment has not been reached yet.

original_sent: So I, you know, I’m—I feel quite comfortable that we can—in particular, that we can raise interest rates at the appropriate time, even if the balance sheet remains large for an extended period.
text_output:
HAWKISH
The speaker expresses comfort in raising interest rates at the appropriate time, even if the balance sheet remains large for an extended period. This suggests a willingness to tighten monetary policy, which is a hawkish stance.

original_sent: And that is a statement about productivity growth, which has been pretty disappointing.
text_output: DOVISH - The sentence suggests that productivity growth has been disappointing, which could imply that the economy is not performing as well as expected. This could lead to a dovish stance, as the FOMC may consider easing monetary policy to stimulate economic growth.

original_sent: But I think that that’s a prudent move, to move in a gradual way to remove Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL accommodation, with unemployment now—and not only, I should say, the unemployment rate, but I think any indicator of labor market performance and tightness that you could look at, whether it’s household perceptions of the availability of jobs, difficulty that firms report in hiring workers, the rate at which workers are quitting their jobs, the rate of job openings, all of these indicators do signal a tight labor market.

DOVISH

original_sent: We have a much more resilient, stronger banking system, and we’re not seeing some worrisome buildup in leverage or credit growth at successive levels.1 So, you know, this is something that the FOMC pays attention to, but if you ask me, is this a significant factor shaping monetary policy now, well, it’s on the list of risks, it’s not a major—it’s not a major factor.
text_output:
NEUTRAL

original_sent: Now, members of the Committee have different views about why this is likely to be true, that the funds rate—when the labor market is normalized and inflation is back to our objective—they maybe have slightly different views on exactly why it’s likely to be the case that interest rates will be a little lower than they would in the longer run.
text_output:
NEUTRAL

The sentence does not express a clear stance on monetary policy. It simply states that members of the Committee have different views on why interest rates may be slightly lower than they would be in the longer run, once the labor market is normalized and inflation is back to the objective.

original_sent: And, at a high level, yes, I would say, and I’ve said before, that it’s really fiscal policy that is more powerful and that has much more to do with—fiscal policy can do those things that will increase the longer-run growth rate of the United States by improving productivity and labor force September 18, 2019 participation and the skills and aptitudes of workers.

NEUTRAL

The sentence does not express a clear stance on monetary policy. Instead, it emphasizes the importance of fiscal policy in improving the longer-run growth rate of the United States by improving productivity and labor force participation.

original_sent: When, when you get to—in, in the forecast, all of that, you know, supply and demand sides of the economy adapt.
text_output: NEUTRAL - The sentence does not express a clear stance on monetary policy. It simply discusses the adaptation of the supply and demand sides of the economy in relation to forecasting.

original_sent: And as I mentioned, I think at the last press conference, estimates by the—by members of the Committee have moved down by a full percentage point since maybe 2012 as we’ve learned—as unemployment has dropped and inflation hasn’t really reacted.
text_output: DOVISH - The sentence suggests that the estimates by members of the Committee have moved down by a full percentage point since 2012, indicating a need for easing of the monetary policy. The reason cited for this is the drop in unemployment and lack of reaction in inflation.

text_output: NEUTRAL - The sentence does not indicate any bias towards tightening or easing of monetary policy. It simply states that the policy approach does not involve intentionally trying to raise inflation.

The sentence does not express a clear stance on monetary policy. It simply acknowledges the volatility of inflation measures.

original_sent: But, first, on inflation expectations, it is true that the breakevens from the inflation-adjusted—inflation-indexed bonds have come down.
text_output: NEUTRAL - The sentence does not express a clear stance on monetary policy. It is simply acknowledging a fact about inflation expectations and the decrease in breakevens from inflation-indexed bonds.

original_sent: So let me start with the question pertaining to exchange rates.
text_output: NEUTRAL - The sentence does not provide any indication of a hawkish or dovish stance towards monetary policy. It is simply a statement introducing a topic of discussion.

original_sent: That’s probably related to gas prices and also just stock prices to some extent for other people.

original_sent: The Committee, based on its assessment at each meeting, has felt comfortable saying that, based on its assessment of those factors, it considers that it will be likely appropriate to maintain the current target range for a considerable time after the asset purchase program ends, especially if inflation remains below the 2 percent objective.

DOVISH

original_sent: With unemployment still elevated and inflation below the Committee’s longer-run objective, the Committee is continuing its highly accommodative policies.

original_sent: So it’s a serious economic problem for the United States, but it’s—it’s got underlying causes that are not related to monetary policy or to our response to the pandemic.

NEUTRAL

The sentence does not express any clear stance on monetary policy. original_sent: These headwinds—which include developments abroad, subdued household formation, and meager productivity growth—could persist for some time.
text_output:
NEUTRAL
The sentence does not express a clear stance on monetary policy, but rather describes potential challenges to the economy that may persist in the future.

original_sent: That said, many of my colleagues and I would see a portion of the decline in the unemployment rate as perhaps not representing a diminution of slack in the labor market.
text_output: DOVISH - The sentence suggests that the decline in the unemployment rate may not necessarily indicate an improvement in the labor market, which implies a cautious approach towards tightening monetary policy.

original_sent: Also, the Committee will pay close attention to measures of inflation expectations to ensure that those expectations remain well anchored.
text_output: NEUTRAL - The sentence does not indicate any bias towards tightening or easing of monetary policy. It simply states that the Committee will monitor inflation expectations to ensure they remain stable.

original_sent: And I’ll discuss the thinking behind today’s interest rate reduction and then turn to the path forward.
text_output: NEUTRAL - The sentence does not express a clear stance on monetary policy. It simply states that the speaker will discuss the reasoning behind a recent interest rate reduction and then discuss what comes next.

original_sent: And it’s natural that if it can be employed that, just as monetary policy is doing a lot to try to June 15, 2016 stimulate growth, that fiscal policy should play a role.

NEUTRAL

original_sent: And one reason for that is that long-term interest rates generally embody two factors.
text_output: NEUTRAL - The sentence does not express a clear stance on monetary policy. It simply states a reason for the behavior of long-term interest rates.

original_sent: Now, with inflation below 2 percent, I think it’s appropriate that the labor market be that tight.

original_sent: And I can only say qualitatively that the Committee will continue to look at the evolution of the outlook, try to assess whether unemployment is making sufficient progress towards our objectives, and, in particular, whether the recovery is still continuing.
